newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Tung family's OOIL plans cost cuts-paper.
newsitem.headline: Tung family's OOIL plans cost cuts-paper.

text.p: Orient Overseas International Ltd (OOIL), the shipping group owned by the family of Hong Kong's post-colonial leader, plans a cost-cutting and efficiency drive, the Sunday Morning Post newspaper reported.

New chairman Tung Chee-chen, who took the helm when his elder brother Tung Chee-hwa made his bid to become Chief Executive-designate of Hong Kong, said he aimed to counterbalance the cyclical nature of the shipping business.
The paper quoted the younger Tung as forecasting a free-for-all in the container shipping business if, as expected, the freight rate-setting grouping, the Anscon Conference, is broken up next year.
The United States and Europe have led the attacks on the conference, accusing it of cartel-like behaviour, the Post said.

Tung said he saw over-capacity and waning demand affecting the trans-Pacific and Asian-European routes which traditionally account for 45 percent of unit Orient Overseas Container Lines's (OOCL) trade.
The strong U.S. dollar and slowdown in the electronics sector have hit the container shipping business, he said.
